'''''Laccaria bicolor''''' is a small tan-colored [[mushroom]] with lilac [[lamella (mycology)|gills]]. It is [[edible mushroom|edible]], but not palatable, and grows in mixed [[birch]] and [[pine]] woods. It is found in the [[temperate zones]] of the globe, in late summer and autumn.<ref name=Phillips06>{{cite book |author=Roger Phillips |year=2006 |title=Mushrooms |publisher=Pan MacMillan |isbn=978-0-330-44237-4}}</ref> ''L. bicolor'' is an [[ectomycorrhiza]]l fungus used as a [[soil inoculant]] in [[agriculture]] and [[horticulture]].

==Taxonomy==
It was initially [[species description|described]] as a [[subspecies (biology)|subspecies]] of ''[[Laccaria laccata]]'' by French [[mycologist]] [[René Maire]] in 1937, before being raised to species rank by [[P.D. Orton]] in 1960.<ref name="Orton 1960"/> Like others in its genus it has the common name of 'Deceiver', because of its propensity to fade and become hard to identify.<ref name="Money 2011">{{cite book |author=Money NP. |title=Mushroom |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OinOUZQmcdQC&pg=PA73 |year=2011 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-973256-2 |page=73}}</ref>

==Description==
The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|2|–|4.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} across, convex to flat, and with a central navel. It is often incurved at the margin, and is various shades of ochraceous-buff, and tan, depending on moisture content. The fibrillose [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is the same color, and with a distinct lilac down towards the base. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is whitish, tinged with pink, or ochraceous, and has no apparent distinctive smell, or taste. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are pale lilac at first, fading paler. The [[spore]]s are white.<ref name=Phillips06/> The picture on the right shows young specimens with quite vivid coloration. More often, they are found [http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/loadimage.asp?did=9057&blockName=Laccaria%20bicolor duller in appearance.]<ref name=Phillips06/>

==Distribution and habitat==
This species is [[mycorrhizal]] with a range of trees, and is found throughout the [[temperate]] zones of the world, in summer and autumn.  This includes [[temperate]] and [[boreal forest]]s of North America and probably Northern Europe.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Mueller GM, Gardes M. |year=1991 |title=Intra- and interspecific relations within ''Laccaria bicolor sensu lato'' |journal=Mycological Research |volume=95 |issue=5 |pages=592–601 |doi=10.1016/s0953-7562(09)80073-7}}</ref> It seems to prefer [[birch]] and [[pine]] woods.<ref name=Phillips06/>

==Carnivory==
''Laccaria bicolor'' is one of a number of species of [[Carnivorous fungus|carnivorous fungi]], but one of the few that catches and kills [[insect]]s, specifically [[springtail]]s.<ref name=carnivore>{{Cite journal | last1 = Klironomos | first1 = J. N. | last2 = Hart | first2 = M. M. | journal = Nature | volume = 410 | issue = 6829 | pages = 651–2 | year = 2001 | doi = 10.1038/35070643 | pmid =  11287942| pmc = | title=Food-web dynamics. Animal nitrogen swap for plant carbon}}</ref>

==Ectomycorrhizae==
This species forms ectomycorrhizal associations with a wide variety of tree species, such as [[red pine]], [[jack pine]], and [[black spruce]].<ref name=Richter1989>Richter DL, Bruhn JN. (1989). Field survival of containerized red and jack pine seedlings inoculated with mycelial slurries of ectomycorrhizal fungi. ''New Forest'' '''3''': 247–258.</ref><ref name=Richter1993>Richter DL, Bruhn JN. (1993). Mycorrhizal colonization of ''Pinus resinosa'' Ait. transplanted on northern hardwood clearcuts. ''Soil Biology and Biochemistry'' '''25''': 335–369.</ref><ref>Wong KKY, Piche Y, Fortin JA. (1990). Differential development of root colonization among four closely related genotypes of ectomycorrhizal ''Laccaria bicolor''. ''Mycological Research'' '''90'''(7): 876–884.</ref> Studies have shown that ''L. bicolor'' is more effective in early colonization of pine roots compared to other ectomycorrhiza forming fungi.<ref name=Richter1989 /><ref>Buschena CA, Doudrick RL, Anderson NA. (1992). Persistence of ''Laccaria'' spp. as ectomycorrhizal symbionts of container grown black spruce. ''Canadian Journal of Forest Research'' '''22''': 1883–1887.</ref> In field studies, it preferentially colonizes and improves the survival of red pine.<ref name=Richter1989 /><ref name=Richter1993 /> Actinobacteria isolates, e.g. from the genus ''Streptomyces'', obtained from old growth [[Norway spruce]] field sites have been shown to stimulate the growth of ''Laccaria bicolor'' in the laboratory. <ref name="Schrey-et-al-2012">{{cite journal | last1=Schrey | first1=Silvia D. | display-authors=etal | year=2012 | title=Production of fungal and bacterial growth modulating secondary metabolites is widespread among mycorrhiza-associated streptomycetes | journal=BMC Microbiology | volume=12 | issue=1| pages=164 | doi=10.1186/1471-2180-12-164| pmid=22852578 | pmc=3487804 }}</ref>

==Genome==
''Laccaria bicolor'' was the first ectomycorrhizal fungus to have its [[Full genome sequencing|genome sequenced]].<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Martin | first1 = F.| last2 = Selosse | first2 = M.| title = The ''Laccaria'' genome: a symbiont blueprint decoded| journal = New Phytologist| volume = 180| issue = 2| pages = 296–310| year = 2008| pmid = 19138220| doi = 10.1111/j.1469-8137.2008.02613.x| citeseerx = 10.1.1.457.2388}}</ref> The genome is 65 [[megabase]]s long and is estimated to contain 20,000 protein coding genes. Analysis revealed a large number of small secreted proteins of unknown function, several of which are only [[expression (genetics)|expressed]] in symbiotic tissues, where they probably play a role in initiating symbiosis. It lacks [[enzyme]]s that are able to degrade [[plant cell wall]]s but does possess enzymes which can degrade other [[polysaccharide]]s, revealing how it is able to grow both in soil and in association with plants.<ref>{{Cite journal| last1 = Martin | first1 = F.| last2 = Aerts | first2 = A.| last3 = Ahrén | first3 = D.| last4 = Brun | first4 = A.| last5 = Danchin | first5 = E.| last6 = Duchaussoy | first6 = F.| last7 = Gibon | first7 = J.| last8 = Kohler | first8 = A.| last9 = Lindquist | first9 = E.| last10 = Pereda | first10 = V.| last11 = Salamov | first11 = A.| last12 = Shapiro | first12 = H. J.| last13 = Wuyts | first13 = J.| last14 = Blaudez | first14 = D.| last15 = Buée | first15 = M.| last16 = Brokstein | first16 = P.| last17 = Canbäck | first17 = B.| last18 = Cohen | first18 = D.| last19 = Courty | first19 = P. E.| last20 = Coutinho | first20 = P. M.| last21 = Delaruelle | first21 = C.| last22 = Detter | first22 = J. C.| last23 = Deveau | first23 = A.| last24 = Difazio | first24 = S.| last25 = Duplessis | first25 = S.| last26 = Fraissinet-Tachet | first26 = L.| last27 = Lucic | first27 = E.| last28 = Frey-Klett | first28 = P.| last29 = Fourrey | first29 = C.| last30 = Feussner | first30 = I.| title = The genome of Laccaria bicolor provides insights into mycorrhizal symbiosis| journal = Nature| volume = 452| issue = 7183| pages = 88–92| year = 2008| pmid = 18322534| doi = 10.1038/nature06556|bibcode = 2008Natur.452...88M | doi-access = free}}</ref>
